4.text:
Vince Cable: Well, thanks for asking me to
this amazing place you've got.

7.text:
I'm afraid I feel a bit like an extraterrestrial,
who sort of wandered in from the world of

13.text:
ties and suits, where people still write in
pen and ink, and things of that kind.

19.text:
But, actually, maybe that's a good place to
start, because I think one of the problems

24.text:
with this crisis is that we all thought we'd
got to the end of history somehow.

30.text:
And nobody remembered what had happened before
with our economy.

35.text:
We'd got into some brave new world where there
are no more booms and busts.

40.text:
And one of the themes of that book which I've
written -- and I've seen a few people with

45.text:
them on their laps, which is a good sign -- is
that you can learn an awful lot from what's

50.text:
happened historically.
If you go back to the 18th century, Britain

56.text:
has had regular booms and busts in the housing
market, approximately every 18 years.

63.text:
It's almost like a metronome.
And people always forget, and they always

68.text:
assume that prices will just go up forever.
But they don't.

72.text:
They boom, they bust, they boom, they bust.
And yet, we had a government, a banking industry,

79.text:
central bankers, regulators, who just assumed
history away.

85.text:
And if you look at the way banks perform -- I
mean, what's this extraordinary paroxysm that

90.text:
we've been through -- we've been through it
before, over and over and over again.

96.text:
The best description that I've encountered
of this present credit crunch is found in

104.text:
the pages of John Stuart Mill, who described
banking collapses in the earlier part of the

109.text:
19th century -- how they're caused, how they
peak, and what happens afterwards, i.e. the

116.text:
credit crunch.
Beautifully described, almost to the detail

122.text:
of what's happened now.
So, you know, there are lessons from the past.

126.text:
We're not in a fundamentally different era.
But, if I can change my metaphors a bit, try

135.text:
to capture what I think has happened and where
we are, the image I use -- and some of you

142.text:
may have heard me use this before, but I think
it's a reasonably good one -- that the British

147.text:
economy in the last two years has had a massive
heart attack, in effect.

152.text:
I mean, clearly, in post-war era, we've had
periods of booms and busts, we've had flu,

159.text:
we've had excitements of various kind.
But what's happened this time is a really

166.text:
big attack.
But -- and this is the positive side of it,

170.text:
you know -- the patient has survived.
The patient is in Intensive Care Unit, still

177.text:
breathing, showing signs of life, thinking
about what happens when they go home from

182.text:
hospital.
But, it is in the hospital, it's had a very

186.text:
bad heart attack, and it's survived because
of extraordinary modern economic medicine.

193.text:
I said, well, there are historical precedents.
But what's been applied this time -- mainly

199.text:
due to the insights of a handful of people
led by the Governor of the Federal Reserve

204.text:
in the United States, Ben Bernanke -- is a
cocktail of extremely powerful economic drugs

212.text:
that have kept the patient going.
And it's a combination of drastic cuts in

217.text:
interest rates, the use of what's called 'monetary
easing' -- quantitative easing -- the deliberate

223.text:
creation of credit, vast, vast budget deficits,
the nationalization or semi-nationalization

232.text:
of banks, and -- in the case of the U.K -- a
very hefty devaluation, 25, 30 percent, depending

240.text:
whether you're talking about the Euro or the
dollar.

243.text:
Now, all those thing together have had an
impact -- of course they have -- and the patient

247.text:
is now showing signs of life.
But there is a big question about, What happens

253.text:
after a heart attack? And I'll come back to
that in a moment.

257.text:
But, before going on to what happens next,
let me just try and break down the attack

263.text:
into its component parts, because it's quite
a complicated economic phenomenon that we've

269.text:
been living through.
Different things have been happening and interacting.

274.text:
The first thing which happened was that there
was a massive asset bubble in our economy

280.text:
-- also in the United States, in Spain, Ireland
 -- but very much in the U.K.

284.text:
An extraordinary bubble in asset prices, particularly
property prices.

290.text:
And, as I say, there are historical trends,
which you could have seen this coming.

295.text:
But it happened, it reached its peak, roughly
two years ago -- 18 months ago -- and has

302.text:
since burst.
And I was talking this morning to the commercial

307.text:
property industry.
There, industry's asset values have gone down

312.text:
by 35, 40 percent.
Domestic property prices haven't yet in the

317.text:
U.K.
gone down anything like the extent to which

321.text:
they should have done.
Now, there is a big question about whether

324.text:
that's an interrupt in process or whether
something very funny is happening in the property

329.text:
market.
But we've had a big asset bubble, it's burst,

333.text:
it's burst spectacularly in commercial property.
It's also burst spectacularly in the States.

338.text:
Residential property prices have gone down
30, 40 percent averaging over the States.

343.text:
Of course, it varies.
And that has fed back into the banking system.

348.text:
And one of the reasons the banks got into
trouble was because they overinvested in risky

353.text:
property transactions.
H Boss went down because of commercial property.

358.text:
Bradford & Bingley because of "Buy-to-let."
All banks because of mortgage lending.

362.text:
So that's the first element -- the asset bubble
that burst.

367.text:
The second element was the collapse of the
banks.

371.text:
And it's a remarkable phenomenon.
I try to describe it in the book.

375.text:
But I don't think any of us have quite got
our heads around the fact that this extraordinarily

381.text:
sophisticated banking system, full of very,
very clever people -- and extremely clever

387.text:
people, the brightest people of their generation
 -- could have produced an industry that just

392.text:
collapsed like a pack of cards.
And there is an important question as to why

398.text:
this happened.
Why was it allowed to happen? What were the

402.text:
dynamics of it?
I'm simplifying a very complicated story.

409.text:
And I think the two key elements in the failure
of the banking system: One was excessive complexity

416.text:
-- complexity which outstripped the capacity
of the managers, the bankers themselves, to

423.text:
understand the products they were dealing
with -- combined with extraordinary leverage.

429.text:
You know, the big investment banks with a
gearing ratio of 50, you know?

435.text:
Loan to equity. Unbelievable.
And this was regarded as a viable business

440.text:
model until it collapsed.
But what essentially was going on was that,

445.text:
within the banking industry, the industry
was lending subprime borrowers in the United

453.text:
States -- low-income families.
And they thought they were doing good -- but

457.text:
that's a sort of micro-story, the mortgage
lending to those -- subprime lending.

462.text:
What was important about it wasn't that it
did that lending -- and that happens -- was

468.text:
that the loans were sold.
You got the phenomenon that was called 'securitization'.

474.text:
Loans were marketed.
The link between the lenders and their clients

479.text:
was broken because of this new kind of monetization
of credit products.

484.text:
And they were sold.
And they were sold again and sold again and

489.text:
spliced and diced in very, very complex combinations.
And very, very clever people were hired in

497.text:
order to create these products.
I don't need to go into the technicalities

503.text:
of it, but just as a little anecdote that
illustrates it: My youngest son was a mathematician

509.text:
at Cambridge -- four or five years ago, five
or six years ago -- and all the people at

514.text:
the top of the faculty were approached by
bankers and said, "Look, you want to come

520.text:
work for us?
50K to start, 100K at the end of the year.”

524.text:
You know, my son -- like most of his contemporaries
 -- knew absolutely nothing about money.

530.text:
I mean, a lovely guy, but managing a bank
account was way beyond -- you know, being

534.text:
invited to join the banking industry and produce
rocket-science products.

538.text:
And, of course, the industry lost track of
the underlying assets which they had on their

545.text:
books.
And there's a very powerful image, which is

549.text:
used in a book by somebody called Jillian
Tett -- I don't know whether you've seen her

554.text:
stuff -- writes for the Financial Times beautifully,
and produced, I think, probably the best book

559.text:
on the crisis.
And she says, "The way to think about this

563.text:
is, It's a bit like a sausage factory.
What the big banks were doing -- or at least

569.text:
certainly through their investment banking
operations -- they were operating like a sausage

574.text:
factory, which bought in meat from abattoirs
all over the place, who in turn brought in

579.text:
meat from hundreds or thousands of farmers.
And they chewed this stuff up and padded out

586.text:
the sausage, put skins around it, made money
as manufacturers, sold it into a willing consumer

593.text:
market -- everybody likes sausages.
And it was a great industry, and a lot of

597.text:
people made money out of it.
Until, suddenly, somebody uttered the dreaded

601.text:
words "BSC".
And you know, What happens when somebody says

606.text:
Where are the bad cows?
How are we going to get the stuff off the

610.text:
shelves?
Nobody knew where it was -- all mixed up.

614.text:
And you know, when the panic started to spread,
the banks no longer trusted each other, because

620.text:
they didn't know where the bad debts were.
You got a complete collapse of trust in the

626.text:
system.
And markets can't function without trust.

629.text:
And they eventually dried up and you got to
the point, which the Governor of the Bank

634.text:
of England described last week -- I think
it was last week -- as, "24 hours from the

640.text:
complete collapse of the whole banking system,"
because banks no longer trusted each other

644.text:
to lend overnight.
It had got to that stage.

647.text:
And that was the point at which governments
had to intervene and prevent complete and

652.text:
total meltdown.
So in a very, very abbreviated way, that was

659.text:
what happened in the banking system.
Of course, there are many ramifications of

662.text:
it.
So those are two elements: The asset bubble

665.text:
and the banking collapse.
And the third element -- which to some extent

670.text:
was a consequence of those two things -- was
a classic recession.

676.text:
Consumers stopped spending last October, November.
They turned on the ten o'clock news -- Robert

682.text:
Peston -- everybody getting into a blind panic.
People in this country started worrying about

688.text:
their consumer debts, big mortgages.
And it's worth remembering that the U.K. household

695.text:
debts in relation to people's incomes is the
highest in the developed world, and probably

701.text:
higher than at any stage in our history.
And people started looking at their domestic

706.text:
balance sheets and panicking and stopped spending.
And then, that triggered a recession, fed

711.text:
through into the retail sector.
Retail ____ have probably contracted by 20

716.text:
percent.
You know, Woolworth's, or the more visible

718.text:
bits of it.
That fed through into the supply chains -- manufacturing,

723.text:
services, your advertisers, the lot.
Spread overseas into the exporting countries

728.text:
-- China initially.
Japan and Germany were all hit very badly,

733.text:
because the big consuming markets -- the United
States particularly, in some sense ourselves

738.text:
-- started contracting.
And so, it became global.

741.text:
So you had all these three things feeding
into each other -- asset market failure, banking

747.text:
collapse, recession -- reinforcing each other.
And it was a massive attack.

754.text:
Massive attack.
We hadn't seen anything on the scale since

759.text:
'29, the Great Crash, the Interwar period.
But, unlike the crash of the Interwar period,

766.text:
this has not -- at least, so far, and I think
probably hasn't -- proved fatal.

773.text:
Two big reasons for that.
First of all, governments and central banks

777.text:
got it right broadly.
The intervention that our government -- I'm

781.text:
not making a party point here, because that's
not in my interest to do it -- but the government

785.text:
broadly got it right.
The emergency intervention last October was

791.text:
correct -- what had to happen.
And of course, the central banks were the

795.text:
driving force behind it, unlike in the 30's
when governments sat back and watched the

800.text:
crisis develop until it was too late.
And the other thing which happened this time

805.text:
-- and something you'll intuitively understand,
because you're part of the global industry

810.text:
-- is that, although there were a lot of
nationalistic instincts around the place,

816.text:
broadly speaking, governments realized that
they had to hang together rather than hang

821.text:
separately.
You got a cooperative response.

824.text:
Everybody played ball with some grumbling.
The Germans didn't want to be dragged into

828.text:
big, fiscal deficits.
Chinese and Americans blaming each other to

832.text:
some extent.
But at the end of the day, they got down to

835.text:
it and worked together.
And that's been the remarkable outcome of

839.text:
this crisis.
That you actually had governments -- many

842.text:
of which hate each other -- actually cooperating
and dealing with it in a collaborative way.

848.text:
And those two things have -- I think to a
large extent -- saved the day.

854.text:
But the question is, you know, Where do we
go from here?

859.text:
I'm trying to describe how we got here and
what's happening.

862.text:
But, Where do we go from here?
Particularly in -- I'll start with the U.K.

868.text:
There's been a big switch in mood in the last
few months.

871.text:
Instead of kind of 'manic depression', we've
now got into the kind of 'hyperphase'.

877.text:
You know, recovery, green shoots, all that
stuff.

881.text:
And it is justified to have some degree of
return of confidence.

886.text:
But I would caution against getting carried
away.

889.text:
There are all kind of factors that are dragging
the U.K. economy back.

894.text:
Consumers, heavily indebted, are going to
spend many years de-leveraging, getting their

900.text:
domestic balance sheets back into some sort
of order.

903.text:
So, you're not going to get big spending splurges.
The monetary steroids -- that have been keeping

911.text:
the patient alive -- are going to be withdrawn
in the next year or so.

916.text:
They can't just keep pumping in artificially
 -- injections -- into the monetary system,

921.text:
because otherwise, you then pile up trouble
further down the line.

925.text:
So there's got to be an exit strategy from
that, and we don't know how the patient will

930.text:
respond.
The British economic recovery depends very

935.text:
heavily on exports and import -- competing
industries, because they've had a big boost

941.text:
from the devaluation, which is why the tourist
industry, for example, is doing well.

947.text:
Some manufacturers are doing very well.
But a lot of the export boost -- if that's

952.text:
what it is -- depends on the rest of the world.
And it is certainly true that, in many parts

958.text:
of the world, this whole thing is bottoming
out.

961.text:
Maybe in France, Germany, we're not absolutely
sure, but they seem to be getting on the level.

968.text:
The United States, probably some sort of recovery
next year.

972.text:
And India and China are just roaring away.
So all those things together suggest that

980.text:
you are getting external recovery as well
as internal recovery.

984.text:
That may help the exports to grow.
So that's the one thing that we can seize

990.text:
upon.
The other big downer, unfortunately, is the

995.text:
government.
The government has -- to a very substantial

999.text:
extent -- been keeping the British economy
going through public spending and public capital

1004.text:
investment.
That is not going to continue. Not going to

1008.text:
continue.
The big debate in U.K. politics, which I'm

1014.text:
part of, is how we deal with the fact that
we've now got horrendous government borrowing.

1021.text:
I don't want to be moralistic about it.
I think the government had to borrow heavily

1025.text:
in a recession -- and I have a separate argument
with the Tories about this -- but they had

1032.text:
to do it.
But we now have an enormous borrowing requirement.

1037.text:
Let's just reflect just to why that's happened
and how it's happened.

1042.text:
British tax revenue has collapsed.
The share of the British economy in the form

1048.text:
of taxation is now about 35 percent.
That's lower than at any time since I was

1055.text:
a child -- Harold MacMillan's day.
And basically, you may not feel like it, but

1061.text:
you live in a low-tax economy -- not achieved
by design, but simply because a key element

1067.text:
of the tax base has disappeared, which is
the financial sector and, to some extent,

1071.text:
the housing market.
So you've had a collapse of tax revenue -- not

1075.text:
just because of the recession, but because
structurally, some of the key elements of

1081.text:
tax revenue have gone.
So you've got a collapse of tax revenue and

1085.text:
you've got government spending continuing
to rise.

1088.text:
You know, recession -- more people unemployed,
government charging in -- trying to prop up

1093.text:
the housing market, trying to prop up the
car industry, all those things.

1097.text:
So government spending continuing to rise
to what -- 48, 49, 50 percent of GDP.

1103.text:
So the difference between what it's spending
and what it's getting in tax is about 13,

1108.text:
14 percent of GDP.
It is an astronomic figure by most standards.

1112.text:
And that's now having to be borrowed in money
markets.

1116.text:
At the moment, it isn't a problem.
The markets are perfectly happy to lend to

1121.text:
the British government and the Americans,
who've got similar deficits, less structural,

1126.text:
but the Americans have got a similar scale,
because absolute terms it's much bigger, because

1131.text:
America is a bigger economy.
Both the two, big, Anglo-Saxon countries borrowing

1135.text:
massively from financial markets.
They're happy to do it at the moment, borrowing

1141.text:
very cheaply, two percent rio, you know, it's
not a big deal.

1146.text:
But the worry is that sometime, down the track,
markets will look at the U.K. and say, "Well,

1156.text:
is this a viable model?”
You know, you can't just keep borrowing like

1159.text:
this.
Debt piles up. Debt service grows.

1162.text:
There is then an adjustment. Their interest
rates go up.

1166.text:
That, in turn, pushes up your debt servicing.
It then becomes very, very serious.

1171.text:
And that's why the political debate has now
switched on to this whole issue of cuts, or

1177.text:
taxes -- do it two ways.
But the significance of it -- from what I'm

1182.text:
saying -- is that nobody believes now that
the government can continue to drive the economy

1188.text:
through spending and investment. It can't.
It's going to have a negative effect.

1192.text:
So the question then is, Where is this growth
going to come from?

1196.text:
And I've been down the list.
And apart from exports, it's difficult to

1201.text:
see.
So, the outcome of that analysis would be,

1207.text:
Plenty of signs of returning confidence, but
fairly anemic.

1214.text:
I don't want to get into the forecasting arguments
about whether it's 'double-dip recessions'

1218.text:
or 'flattening out' and so on.
But, I mean, you get the trend of my argument.

1223.text:
So that's all I really want to say about where
we are and where we're going from here.

1227.text:
I just want to finish up with flagging up
some of the big, difficult, long-term issues

1234.text:
that we've got to try and face coming out
of this crisis.

1237.text:
The first one, I've sort of half touched on
already, which is what kind of economic structure

1244.text:
this country's going to have five, ten years,
20 years down the track.

1249.text:
I mean, How is the British economy going to
change?

1252.text:
It's very clear that we became over-dependent
on financial services -- not that all financial

1257.text:
services are a bad thing. Clearly, they're
not.

1259.text:
And many of the things that are happening
in the City are very useful.

1262.text:
But we became over-dependent on a source of
revenue growth -- employment tax revenue -- that

1269.text:
was just too unstable.
And then, we were almost in the position of

1274.text:
Iceland -- not quite as extreme, but over-dependent
on the banking sector.

1280.text:
So, relatively speaking, that's going to have
to contract.

1284.text:
So what's going to grow in its place?
Well, new forms of trade-able activities and

1290.text:
manufacturing -- not necessarily metal-bashing,
but industry in the widest sense, including

1296.text:
creative industries.
That's the space that's going to have to be

1300.text:
occupied.
That raises questions about whether, as a

1302.text:
country, we've got the skills, the education,
to make it happen.

1308.text:
That's where we have to start looking.
Second big question is, What do you do about

1313.text:
this very big, financial sector that's fouled
up seriously -- caused a lot of damage?

1321.text:
And here, I think -- although the government
was broadly right last October -- they have

1326.text:
completely taken their eyes off the ball.
Haven't focused, for example, on how you make

1332.text:
sure that the banks that have been rescued
 -- make sure that capital gets out to solvent

1337.text:
companies.
A lot of companies are still going by the

1339.text:
ball, because the banks have stopped lending.
They've lurched from, you know, ludicrously

1344.text:
excessive lending to ultra-conservative lending.
The government, in my view, should have stepped

1348.text:
in and smoothed it out.
But they have a complicated problem because

1353.text:
of the role of regulation.
But it's not worked.

1356.text:
But looking beyond that, How do we make sure
that the big banks are structured in such

1362.text:
a way that they don't destabilize the British
economy anymore?

1365.text:
And let's not forget, Britain is the center
for the world's big banks.

1371.text:
Three out of the five biggest banks of the
world, in balance sheet terms, were British

1377.text:
in the run-up to this crisis.
RBS -- which is the biggest bank in the world

1386.text:
HSBC floated away reasonably comfortably,
having been very well-managed.

1393.text:
Lloyds, another very big bank, has gone down
 -- dragged down by H Boss.

1396.text:
So we've had a very, very big banking sector
 -- exceptionally large banking sector -- and

1401.text:
the question is how you restructure.
Lots of technical arguments here.

1407.text:
But my very simple view is that we can not
continue to have the situation where you have

1413.text:
very, very large banks, which take big risks
in their international activity, which then,

1420.text:
when they overreach themselves, have to be
underwritten by the British taxpayer.

1423.text:
We can't allow this situation to happen again.
And that means, probably, we're going to have

1429.text:
to have a dual system where you have, on the
one hand, competitive banks -- that don't

1435.text:
depend on taxpayer support -- go out and do
their own thing, hedge funds or whatever -- take

1440.text:
risks -- commercial, business-minded, purely
private sector.

1446.text:
They can stand or fail by their own competitive
performance.

1450.text:
And then, on the other hand, you have utilities,
which are run and regulated like water companies,

1456.text:
which don't take risks, -- except on a kind
of microlevel with small business -- are run

1461.text:
very safely, provide credit to normal business
customers, take your deposits, and operate

1469.text:
in a very traditional, conservative way.
I think that has to be the clear separation

1474.text:
at some point in the next few years.
So that's the second question.

1481.text:
How do you sort out the financial sector?
I don't think the government's even begun,

1485.text:
really, to get to grips with that.
And the third and the final point I want to

1488.text:
make and I'll finish on this now.
I think the one major thing that's affected

1493.text:
the world in all this is that, it's changed
the center of gravity of the world economy

1500.text:
in a quite radical way.
Until this crisis, it became part of the conventional

1505.text:
wisdom that China and India were becoming
major powers.

1510.text:
Their GNP, measured in purchasing power terms,
put them right up at the top.

1518.text:
China -- before the crisis -- was the second
biggest economy in the world.

1521.text:
India probably the fourth, if you measure
it properly.

1526.text:
You know, we all taught about this.
But I don't think -- until this crisis happened

1530.text:
-- we've quite realized how important these
countries are economically.

1536.text:
I remember, only a few years ago, the Governor
of Hong Kong, Chris Patten, coming back and

1541.text:
saying on television, "Don't get so excited
about China.

1545.text:
It's only got an economy the size of Belgium.”
You begin to realize it's taken an awful long

1551.text:
time to call on board what's happening in
the real world.

1554.text:
You know, these are very big countries with
very big economies that make a big difference.

1559.text:
And when they move, they move big, and they
suck in vast amounts of oil and commodities.

1566.text:
China was pumping out vast quantities of cheap
